Getting Started with IoT in SAP Asset Performance Management

Introduction

With the latest release 2510 of SAP Asset Performance Management (APM), major features in the context of device connectivity and management were enabled and are available as part of the Early Adopter Care (EAC) program. These features utilize the embedded IoT capabilities powered by Cumulocity.

Only two months after its introduction in version 2506 (see also this blog article describing the initial release), many IoT centric features such as direct integration support for OT (operations technology) protocols like OPC-UA, real-time data ingestions via MQTT and REST, live dashboards, streaming analytics and advanced software- and firmware management of devices are now available to SAP Asset Performance Management customers as part of the EAC program.

To celebrate this milestone, we wanted to share a series of how-to guides with you.

In this guide it will be demonstrated how a device can be easily connected to the embedded IoT Platform (Cumulocity) and allocate their timeseries data to assets in SAP Asset Performance Management. It can be seen as a retrofit case where a smart sensor is added and can be attached and correlated to existing assets.

If you are looking for a more advanced way to connect industrial machines and devices to SAP Asset Performance Management, stay tuned for the next guide where we will leverage OPC-UA. We will also dive into applications for Streaming Analytics, how they work differently than existing APM rules and how to combine the strengths of both analytics engines for best results.

Prerequisites

To follow this guide, the following prerequisites must be fulfilled:

  • You have access to an SAP Asset Performance Management environment with Embedded IoT platform
  • You have a smartphone (iOS or Android)

Step-by-Step Guide

Download and Install the Cumulocity Sensor App

To get started, first of all we need a smartphone to install the Cumulocity Sensor App. It is available on the following stores:

  • Google Play Store: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.softwareag.cumulocity.iotcloudsensor
  • Apple App Store: https://apps.apple.com/us/app/cumulocity-iot-sensor-app/id1516838930 

Connect the App to Your Tenant

As a next step you can go to your provided Cumulocity Tenant → Cockpit App and hit the button "Connect smartphone". A wizard will guide you through the steps to scan a QR code with the app. In the final step of the wizard, you can click on "Open Device" to jump to the dashboard that has been created for your smartphone. 

 

Review Dashboard

In the default dashboard created for your smartphone, you can already see a Iot of useful things including:

  • The location of your device
  • Acceleration sensor values
  • Luxometer of your camera
  • Signal Strength and many more
 

 

Creating Indicators in SAP Asset Performance Management

With the data in Cumulocity you can now focus on assigning it to technical objects in SAP Asset Performance Management. In our case, we assume that the phone is attached to a "Cooling Water Circulation Pump" but you can assign it to any other asset of your choice. The acceleration sensor is used to detect vibration, similar to a retrofit sensor with a separate mobile uplink.

As a next step, we need to create indicators that represent our acceleration measurements. Follow the SAP documentation to create indicators for your selected asset.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP APM/8c95dca44fda4d56a17f6494f421758d/0b68eeb8daab49b2ac042ae90955e51f.html?locale=en-US&version=LATEST

Finally, copy the ID of the technical object you want to use for the further steps. It's displayed under the name of the asset in the top left corner.

Assign Data Points to Indicators

Navigate to the Embedded IoT platform, via the "Manage Devices" tile on the SAP Asset Performance Management Launchpad. Within the platform, switch to the "Digital Twin Manager" application via the top right application picker.

Since assets in SAP Asset Performance Management are automatically synced with the Embedded IoT platform, we can search in the Digital Twin Manager for the technical object ID you have copied in the last step to find the corresponding asset in Digital Twin Manager.

Select the asset and navigate to the "Data points" tab. Here you see all indicators as data points. Click on "Link source" and select the data point of your smartphone and demonstrate it on the screen below. Repeat the steps for the two other data points.

 

After successful assignment, the measurement data will be made available within SAP Asset Performance Management.

Review data in SAP Asset Performance Management

Back in SAP Asset Performance Management, we can navigate to our selected technical object and check if data is already available.

To view the indicators in SAP Asset Performance Management, select them for monitoring like demonstrated below.

Great, you have the data of your retrofit sensor successfully assigned to your technical object and can leverage SAP Asset Performance Management to use it for further use cases.

Conclusion & Next Steps

This guide demonstrated how you can quickly integrate a device to Embedded IoT powered by Cumulocity and assign its measurement data to an existing technical object in SAP Asset Performance Management.

In the next guide, we will use OPC-UA to integrate an industrial device to Cumulocity with multiple data points and assign it to an asset.

entry.title: Embedded IoT is here: 5 apps that accelerate sensor to insight in SAP Asset Performance Management
entry.content:
Over the past months Early Adopter Care program participants, were gradually ramped up with additional capabilities powered by the Embedded IoT platform. With SAP Asset Performance Management 2511, we have released the Embedded IoT functionality within SAP Asset Performance Management to all our customers and partners. Customers now benefit from an end-to-end offering that spans from sensor to process action or insights, all within SAP Asset Performance Management - achieving seamless integration of data sources and monitoring of IoT-connected assets, towards establishing condition based maintenance practices.

How does this look

The launchpad of SAP Asset Performance Management now contains 5 new application tiles that are accessible to end-users depending on their assigned business roles. These tiles navigate directly to the respective applications in the IoT platform. Let's briefly run through those apps below.

 

Manage Devices

This helps you connect and manage devices efficiently. It offers a unified platform to onboard, monitor, configure, and control IoT devices throughout their lifecycle—including definition of device protocols, software & configuration management, and more, depending on the capabilities of the connected device or gateway. Many industrial environments use lightweight messaging protocols (e.g., MQTT) to collect telemetry data from machines, devices, and sensors. Embedded IoT now makes it easy to ingest and process this data as it arrives, rather than waiting for batch uploads.

With a new persona, the Device Integration Engineer, customers can now onboard, configure, and monitor devices - capabilities that were not offered in the past and were covered in other systems out side of SAP Asset Performance Management. This opens up new opportunities to get closer to the source of data, or even retrofit installing sensors that are required for maintenance purposes.

For more info, watch this space for more articles to come, and refer to the SAP Help Portal to check out the official docs for getting started.

Manage IoT Dashboards

For near real-time insights and reporting, the Cockpit gives you the flexibility and tools to manage and monitor device data, creating widget-based reports for individual or groups of devices. With this feature, reliability engineers can now access personalised, live, contextual IoT dashboards - unifying sensor data and events - so they detect anomalies immediately on critical assets, flexibly visualize data per their needs, and assist in driving fact-based maintenance decisions.

To quickly get started with a live data feed and exemplary dashboards, you can connect your smartphone in just a minute and explore. See how in the video:

For more info, watch this space for more articles to come, and refer to the SAP Help Portal to check out the official docs for getting started.

Manage Streaming Analytics

Streaming Rules enable enhanced condition monitoring with flow-based models to process time series data in near real-time at individual data point level. This allows for monitoring within the IoT platform, to derive new indicator values, and also triggering of rules within SAP Asset Performance Management. This continuous, real-time feedback loop allows reliability engineers to respond proactively to critical events and implement monitoring and dashboards themselves using low-code tools — capabilities not possible with batch-based monitoring. For more details, have a look at the What's new blog from the 2510 release.

 

For a quick glimpse in how it is working, you can watch this video:

For more info, watch this space for more articles to come, and refer to the SAP Help Portal to check out the official docs for getting started.

Map Devices to Technical Objects

To use the time series for asset management purposes, the sensors from the IoT platform need to be contextualized into the asset semantics using the Digital Twin Manager. The application allows to map devices and their sensors (the OT world) to their corresponding technical objects and indicators from SAP Asset Performance Management (the IT world). Once the connection is established, data is automatically made available into charts, rules engine, and stored into the data lake from SAP Asset Performance Management.

Navigate to technical objects along the technical object hierarchy

Assign measurements from a device to an indicator

For more info, watch this space for more articles to come, and refer to the SAP Help Portal to check out the official docs for getting started.

IoT Platform Administration

Users seamlessly navigate to the applications with out-of-box configured Single Sign-On, and also for data archiving (see Digital Twin Manager), everything is setup automatically. However, some configurations are still relevant for Administrators and can be configured in the IoT Platform Administration application. Examples are the data forwarding between systems, or configuration of Certificate Authorities for device certificates administrators. With the Data Broker, administrators can now setup continuous data feeds between landscapes, i.e. to achieve a near real-time data ingestion into quality / test environments based on incoming data from the production environment.

What's next

Please stay tuned over the next weeks as we publish more articles showcasing the respective capabilities. You can't wait to get started? Check out this recently published blog that describes a brief end-to-end scenario from sensor to insight, using a free simulator app for your mobile phone. See how quick it is to monitor asset conditions, define failure thresholds, and generate maintenance requests using SAP Asset Performance Management.

entry.title: SAP EHS Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side - Guidebook (Part 4)
entry.content:
Integrating SAP EHS Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side - Guidebook

Part 4: Integration of Functional Locations & Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise

Table of Contents:

  • 1. Why is this Integration required?
  • 2. Prerequisites
  • 3. Technical Integration
  • 3.1 SAP S/4HANA On-Premise Configuration
  • 3.2 SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration
  • 3.2.1 Create Communication User
  • 3.2.2 Create Communication System
  • 3.2.3 Create Communication Arrangement
  • 3.3 SAP Integration Suite Configuration
  • 3.3.1Establishing the Event Queue for On-Premise Triggers
  • 3.3.2 Integration Credential Configuration
  • 3.3.3 Integration Flow (iFlow) Setup - Equipment
  • 3.3.4 Integration Flow (iFlow) Setup – Functional Locations
  • 3.4 Monitoring
  • 3.4.1 SAP S/4HANA On-Premise
  • 3.4.2 SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • 3.4.3 SAP Integration Suite
  • 4. Lessons Learned
  • 5. Engage with Us

Related Content:

Below is an overview of the planned blog series – each post focusing on a specific integration topic. Once published, the titles will be linked for direct access:

Integrating SAP EHS in the Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side – Guidebook

Part 1: Introduction & OverviewLink
Part 2: Integration of Employees from SAP SuccessFactorsLink
Part 3: Integration of Business Partners & Material from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG)Link
Part 4: Integration of Functional Locations & Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise SystemLink
Part 5: Extensibility Scenarios & Further ImplementationLink
Part 6: Summary & OutlookLink

 

1. Why is this Integration required?

Integrating Functional Locations and Equipment master data from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise into SAP EHS Public Cloud is a foundational step for enabling core EHS processes such as Risk Management, Incident Management, and Emissions Management. Instead of maintaining asset-related data manually within SAP EHS Public Cloud, the system relies on validated Plant Maintenance (PM) master data coming from the customer’s existing ERP landscape. This ensures that all structures, machines, and technical objects involved in EHS processes remain consistent, reliable, and audit-proof across the enterprise.

Accurate and up-to-date Functional Location and Equipment data is essential because many EHS processes depend on a clear understanding of where work is performed and which technical objects is affected. This includes:

  • Identifying the exact machine or installation involved in an incident
  • Linking hazards to the correct technical asset in Risk Assessments
  • Performing control inspections and assigning follow-up actions
  • Ensuring asset-specific exposure, material usage, or emission characteristics are correctly evaluated
  • Centralizing reporting across operational sites based on real asset hierarchies

In other words: Without integrated Functional Location and Equipment data, SAP EHS Public Cloud cannot reliably assess risks, evaluate hazards, track incidents, or produce compliant operational reports.

Architectural Approach - Scope

The highlighted section of the architectural diagram illustrates the scope relevant to this blog post – focusing on the integration of Functional Locations and Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Reference to User Scenario (B) – Risk Management

In part 1 “Introduction & Overview”, the User Scenario (B) – Risk Management at Mike Machineries (chapter 2.1.1) demonstrated why this integration is required:

Scenario Step

Why Plant Maintenance (PM) Integration Matters

A supervisor identifies a hazard in the chemical handling area

The hazard must be assigned to the correct Functional Location to ensure accurate traceability and reporting.

An Industrial Hygienist conducts a risk assessment

Equipment properties (e.g. ventilation units, storage cabinets, extraction systems) must be available from SAP PM to evaluate exposure and technical conditions.

Mitigation actions are defined

Some mitigation measures depend on technical object (e.g., upgrading ventilation, replacing equipment, updating signage).

A control inspection is performed

The inspection must reference the exact equipment or Functional Location where the mitigation is implemented.

Residual risk is recalculated

The correct asset hierarchy ensures that results are assigned to the right operational area or machine.

Results are shared with operations teams

Consistent Functional Location data ensures findings reach the correct plant, work center, or technical area.

Without integrated Functional Locations and Equipment, the system would not be able to:

  • Assign hazards or incidents to the correct asset
  • Trace risk assessments and inspections to the real technical environment
  • Evaluate machine-specific conditions and exposures
  • Monitor the effectiveness of mitigation actions at asset level
  • Ensure accurate reporting across operational areas and sites

Note: When implementing Risk Management as demonstrated in the user scenario, ensure that the relevant scope item 54A – Health & Safety Management (for Risk Management) is activated in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud via Central Business Configuration (CBC). This activation enables the Risk Assessment and Control Inspection processes in SAP EHS Public Cloud so that synchronized Functional Locations and Equipment master data can be used consistently.

While this integration is mandatory for Risk Management, it is equally relevant for other EHS use cases such as Incident Management or Emissions Management. In all these processes, consistent asset data provides the foundation for identifying affected areas, assessing technical conditions, and enabling accurate regulatory reporting.

 

2. Prerequisites

To successfully integrate Plant Maintenance data from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud via the SAP Integration Suite, the following prerequisites must be fulfilled:

Tenant Provisioning:  

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud tenant 
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise tenant (with activated Plant Maintenance)
  • SAP Integration Suite tenant (Cloud Integration + Event Mesh)

Administrator Access: 

Ensure administrator users exist in all three systems: 

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud: The administrator should have the template role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR assigned to allow the creation of communication users, systems, and arrangements. 
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise: Users with access to the SPRO are required.
  • SAP Integration Suite: A User with admin rights for Event Mesh and iFlow deployment is required.

Scope Item Activation:  

Following scope items need to be activated in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud:

  • 4HH – Reactive Maintenance (mandatory for the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud communication scenario regarding the inbound services for Equipment and Functional Locations).
  • 54A – Health & Safety Management (required for Risk Management scenario).

Activated OData Services in the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise System:

  • API_EQUIPMENT and API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION active in SAP Gateway (check via /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE).

Event Mesh Instance:

  • Provisioned by SAP BTP with service key available (for AMQP connection).

These prerequisites ensure that the integration of Plant Maintenance – specially changes made in SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system – operates smoothly and reliably, thereby supporting EHS processes such as Risk Management.

 

3. Technical Integration

This section provides an overview of the technical integration required to replicate Plant Maintenance master data from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud for EHS processes.

The integration scenario builds on the activation of the scope item 4HH – Reactive Maintenance, which delivers the necessary inbound services for Equipment and Functional Locations in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. These objects form the foundation for EHS capabilities such as Risk Management, Incident Management, or Emissions Management.

The process shown in this integration scenario is event-driven. This means, whenever changes occur to Plant Maintenance master data, such as Equipment or Functional Location in the On-Premise system, these updates are automatically replicated to the Public Cloud. This approach keeps both systems aligned without manual steps or scheduled batch jobs, ensuring that asset information is always current.

Keeping master data synchronized between both systems is critical for effective Risk Management because risk assessments and mitigation strategies depend on accurate details about assets and their locations.

By ensuring that updates flow seamlessly between systems, organizations can make informed decisions and maintain compliance across their EHS processes.

Key Configuration Areas: 

  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise Configuration 
  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration 
  • SAP Integration Suite Configuration
  • Monitoring

3.1 SAP S/4HANA On-Premise Configuration

As this integration scenario for Functional Locations and Equipment is event driven, the creation of channels was required in the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system to publish business events to the SAP Integration Suite via Event Mesh.

In this context the channels define the protocol (AMQP), destination (Event Mesh service key), and topic space.

Outbound bindings specify which event topics (e.g., sap/s4/beh/equipment/v1/Equipment/*) are sent. This ensures that changes in Functional Locations or Equipment trigger the corresponding iFlows in the SAP Integration Suite.

Channels can be created by navigating to SPRO > ABAP Platform > Enterprise Event Enablement > Administration > Chanel Connection Settings > Manage Channels and Parameters.

Therefore, we created the channel IS_INTERNAL_EVENTMESH which uses the AMQP Protocol.

Event Channels in SAP S/4HANA On-Premise

After creating the channel, we added two outbound bindings to define which event topic should be published.

  • sap/s4/beh/equipment/v1/Equipment/*
  • sap/s4/beh/functionallocation/v1/FunctionalLocation/*

Added Outbound Bindings to created Event Channel

This configuration ensures that business events for Functional Locations and Equipment are reliably published from the on-premise system to SAP Integration Suite via Event Mesh, enabling event-driven iFlows without the need for polling.

3.2 SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration

In addition to setting up SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud must also be configured to receive employee master data via the SAP Integration Suite. 

For this purpose, a Communication Arrangement is required to enable secure data exchange between the systems. In this scenario, the predefined Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0395 – Asset Management Master Data Integration is used.

By activating and configuring this Communication Arrangement enables the necessary inbound API services, allowing the SAP Integration Suite to push employee data into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. 

To create the Communication Arrangement, we need to create a Communication User as well as a Communication System that will be assigned to the related Communication Arrangement.

3.2.1 Create Communication User

In this integration scenario, an Inbound Communication User was created in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (e.g., user OPN_IN). This user was used for Basic Authentication in the Communication Arrangement, and its credentials were securely stored in the Security Material of the SAP Integration Suite to enable a safe connection between the systems. 

Select Maintain Communication Users

To create the Inbound Communication User in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, log in to the Fiori Launchpad as an administrator and open the app “Maintain Communication Users”.  

Select "New"

If no suitable user exists, select “New” to create one.

Created Communication User - General Data

The username and password for Basic Authentication can be freely defined. 

Related Communication System and Arrangements

Once created, the system automatically structures the user view, showing assignments to Communication Systems and Arrangements (added in later steps). 

3.2.2 Create Communication System

The Communication System is a necessary component for the Communication Arrangement. If you have already set up a Communication System for the S/4HANA On-Premise system, you can use it for the Communication Arrangement. Please note that the previously created Communication User must be assigned to this system for the following steps. Furthermore, no additional system-level settings (regarding outbound communication) are necessary, as the communication scenario SAP_COM_0395 only uses inbound services.

If no related user exists, you can create a new one as follows: Navigate to the S/4HANA Public Cloud app “Communication Systems”.

Select Communication Systems

Select “New”.

Select "New"

Enter a System ID and System Name referring to the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise tenant and proceed with the set up. 

Creating new Communication System

Select Inbound Only as the communication scenario SAP_COM_0395 only uses Inbound Communication.

Select Inbound Only

Assign the previously created Communication User.

Assign Communication User

3.2.3 Create Communication Arrangement

The final step in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud configuration is to bind the previously created components  (Communication User and Communication System) within the Communication Arrangement (SAP_COM_0395 – Asset Management Master Data Integration). 

Once configured, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is ready to receive replicated Plant Maintenance master data (e. g. Functional Locations or Equipment) from the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system through the SAP Integration Suite. The Communication Arrangement provides the inbound service URLs, which must be stored in the corresponding Integration Flow (iFlow) of the SAP Integration Suite to establish end-to-end communication. 

To create the arrangement, log in to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Fiori Launchpad as an administrator and open the “Communication Arrangements” app. 

Select Communication Arrangements

Then click on “New” to create a new Communication Arrangement. 

Select "New"

Select Communication Scenario SAP_COM_0395

Choose SAP_COM_0395 as the Communication Scenario.

Choose Communication Scenario SAP_COM_0395

After the creation of the Communication Arrangement the before created Communication System will be attached. Note that the corresponding Communication User will be determined automatically.

Communication System and User

The Inbound Service of the Communication Arrangement provides us then the Service URL, that will be used as the receiver endpoint in the iFlow configuration of the SAP Integration Suite.  

Required Inbound Services

3.3 SAP Integration Suite Configuration

In this integration scenario we used the SAP Integration Suite as the middleware layer to enable secure and reliable data exchange between the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Therefore, the SAP Integration Suite is responsible for retrieving Plant Maintenance master data (such as Functional Locations and Equipment) from the On-Premise system and delivering it to the Public Cloud using event-driven integration flows.

Since there is no pre-delivered integration package available for this scenario, we created two custom iFlows to handle the replication of Functional Location and Equipment data. Both iFlows follow a similar structure in terms of processing logic; however, they differ in the endpoints used for communication with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and the On-Premise system respectively.

Custom Integration Package for this Scenario

3.3.1 Establishing the Event Queue for On-Premise Triggers

The first step in this implementation is to create an Event Queue in SAP Event Mesh using the Message Client. This queue serves as the trigger point for event-driven integration. When a change occurs in the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system (such as an update to Functional Locations or Equipment), an event is published to the queue.

The iFlow will be later subscribed to the Event Queue and use the event as a trigger to start processing. Once triggered, the iFlow calls the related API in the On-Premise system to retrieve the full master data for the affected object. This design ensures that updates are replicated to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud in near real-time, keeping both systems synchronized.

Note: The SAP Event Mesh – Message client is typically provisioned by the BASIS administrator. If you have no existing Message Client, please refer to your BASIS team.

Once the message client was set up, navigate to it inside the SAP Integration Suite > Configure > Event Mesh.

Navigate to Message Client in SAP Integration Suite

Since our EHS scenario relates to Functional Locations and Equipment, we have created two separate event queues here. Therefore, select Create.

Select "Create"

Enter a name for the new Event Queue(e. g. opn.equipment). You can keep the remaining fields as default.

Queue Settings for opn.equipment

Then navigate to Subscriptions and select Create.

Select "Create"

Two Topic Subscriptions were required within the Event Queue Details for the Equipment:

  • <message-client-prefix>/ce/sap/s4/beh/equipment/v1/Equipment/Created/v1
  • <message-client-prefix>/de/ce/sap/s4/beh/equipment/v1/Equipment/Changed/v1

Note: Regarding the Subscription, the message-client-prefix will be typically provisioned by your BASIS team. The remaining part of the respective topic names of the Equipment event is SAP standard and can be viewed in the SAP Business Accelerator Hub in the tab Event References Event References | Equipment Events | SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Repeat this step also for the Functional Location. Therefore again, enter a name for the new event queue (e. g. opn.FuncLoc). The following subscriptions are needed for this event queue:

  • <message-client-prefix>/ce/sap/s4/beh/functionallocation/v1/FunctionalLocation/Changed/v1
  • <message-client-prefix>/ce/sap/s4/beh/functionallocation/v1/FunctionalLocation/Created/v1

The Functional Location events for the Functional Locations can be found in the SAP Business Accelerator Hub in the tab Event References Event References | Functional Location Events | SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

3.3.2 Integration Credential Configuration

Within the SAP Integration Suite, the created integration flows (iFlows) must authenticate against three endpoints:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud – to push the synchronized data to the cloud system.
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise – to retrieve Functional Location and Equipment data
  • SAP Event Mesh – to consume events via AMQP protocol and trigger the integration process.

Note: To ensure secure authentication for each endpoint used by the iFlow, a dedicated Security Material object was created for every connection. In our demo environment, Basic Authentication was sufficient; however, for productive landscapes, certificate-based authentication is required to meet security standards and comply with enterprise policies.

For communication with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, Basic Authentication was used in this scenario. The credentials of the Inbound Communication User from SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud must therefore be maintained as Security Material within the SAP Integration Suite. This configuration ensures that the integration flow can authenticate securely when transmitting data to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Security Material

The Security Material that was used for communication with the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system, was created in a similar way using Basic Authentication, based on the credentials of the On-Premise user. Note that the On-Premise user will be provided by your SAP BASIS team.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise Security Material

For the Event Mesh Security Material that enables communication with SAP Event Mesh, OAuth 2.0 was used for authentication. Therefore, enter the Token Service URL, Client ID and Client Secret, which are provided by the service key of your SAP Event Mesh Instance in SAP BTP Cockpit.

SAP Integration Suite - Event Mesh Security Material

3.3.3 Integration Flow (iFlow) Setup - Equipment

Regarding the iFlows we will setup the Equipment Integration iFlow first. Therefore, create the iFlow with a corresponding name, set SAP S/4HANA as Sender and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition as Receiver.

Sender and Receiver Setup for Equipment iFlow

The integration flow starts with an AMQP connection to SAP Event Mesh. This connection allows the iFlow to subscribe to event queues and consume messages whenever Functional Location or Equipment changes occur in the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system. The AMQP protocol ensures reliable, event-driven communication between the systems and acts as the trigger for the subsequent OData calls.

Therefore, connect the Receiver with the Start Message using the Adapter Type AMQP with Websocket as Transport Protocol.

First iFlow Step - AMQP Adapter Setup

The General tab inside the Adapter can stay as default. In the Connection tab you need to add a Host, Port and Path of the Event Mesh Service Key. You will find this Service Key in the Event Mesh Instance of your SAP BTP Cockpit. For Authentication use OAuth 2.0 and add the associated Security Material for Event Mesh (created in the previous step) as Credential Name.

AMQP Adapter Connection Setup

AMQP Adapter Connection Setup

In the Processing tab, add the event queue name for the equipment.

Assign Event Queue opn.equipment to AMQP Adapter

The incoming event message from SAP Event Mesh is delivered in JSON format. Since subsequent processing steps and OData calls require XML, the JSON to XML Converter transforms the payload accordingly. In this scenario, namespace mapping is disabled because the JSON structure does not include namespaces that need to be preserved in the XML output. The remaining parts of the Converter can stay as default.

JSON to XML Converter

After the conversion to XML, we added a Content Modifier. This Content Modifier is used to extract specific values from the XML structure and store them as Message Header and Exchange Properties.

Content Modifier Setup - General

In the Message Header tab, the Content Modifier reads values from the XML payload using XPath and sets them as message headers. In our example, we set the SAP_ApplicationID header with the Functional Location value found at /root/data/Equipment in the XML.

Content Modifier Setup - Message Header

In the Exchange Property tab, the Content Modifier creates two properties by extracting values from the XML payload using XPath: p_eventType from /root/type and p_equipmentno from /root/data/Equipment. These properties are later used to dynamically build the OData request URL for the GET call to the on-premise system.

Content Modifier Setup - Exchange Property

Next, we set a Request Reply with the name Get Equipment Data. This enables us to get the data via OData Adapter from the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system.

Request Reply with OData Adapter to SAP S/4HANA On-Premise System

In the Connection tab of the OData adapter, we define how the integration flow connects to the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system. In our example, the address consists of the virtual host and port provided by the SAP Cloud Connector, followed by the OData service path /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_EQUIPMENT/, which is the standard endpoint for the Equipment API in SAP Gateway. The proxy type is set to “On-Premise”, and the Location ID refers to the configured Cloud Connector destination (can be found in the Master Instance for your Cloud Connector in the SAP BTP Cockpit > Logged in into your Subaccount > Connectivity > Cloud Connectors). Regarding the authentication, was used with the on-premise related Security Material.

Note: We leveraged an existing SAP Cloud Connector configuration to securely connect the SAP Integration Suite to the on-premise system without exposing the real backend host.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Connection

Note that the API_EQUIPMENT is activated in your on-premise system. You can check this via the transaction /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE and searching for the API_EQUIPMENT OData Service.  

In the Processing tab, we configured a GET operation to the Resource Path Equipment. Therefore, click Select.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing

Choose Connection Source Remote. The fields will be automatically filled with the provided data in the Connection tab. Then click on Step 2. If the connection is configured correctly, we will configure the operation and entities here.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 1

Then select the operation “GET”, the Select Entity “Equipment”, the Sub Levels 1 and choose “Select All Fields”.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 2

To retrieve only the changes for the specific Equipment Number, apply a filter on the property ${property.p_equipmentno} that was set in the Content Modifier earlier. Filter for the ValidityEndDate as shown below.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 3

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 4

After retrieving the equipment data from the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system, we ensured with a message mapping step that the structure and fields of the incoming data match with the expected values for the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. For our related message mapping we used a predefined mapping resource (/MM.mmap) created in the iFlow to transform the received data to the expected structure.

Message Mapping 1

Message Mapping 2

After completing the mapping as required for the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Equipment Inbound Service, we set a new Request Reply with an OData V2 adapter to the receiver endpoint of the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Request Reply with OData Adapter to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud System

In the Connection tab add the inbound service URL for the Equipment provided by the Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0395 in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Inbound Service URL for Equipment in Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0395

Choose Proxy Type Internet and add your Security Material that was created for communication with the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud via Basic Authentication.

As we want to send the structure which the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system expects, we need to create new processing details for this OData Adapter. Therefore, choose the Processing tab and navigate to Select.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud OData Adapter Setup - Processing

Choose again the Connection Source Remote. The required details to connect with the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system will be shown here again automatically after the previous details in the Connection tab have been configured. Then navigate to Step 2.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 1

Now choose the Operation Post, Entity Equipment, Sub Levels 1 and Select All Fields. For the Post operation no filters are required.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 2

Note: The iFlow also shows an Exception Subprocess. You can perform this after the implementation of the iFlow is finished. In our scenario we let the Exception Subprocess empty.

Exception Subprocess

3.3.4 Integration Flow (iFlow) Setup – Functional Locations

The iFlow for the Functional Locations was similar in architecture, with small changes.

Created iFlow for Functional Location

For the AMQP Adapter at beginning of the iFlow, the event queue for Functional Location was used.

Used Event Queue in iFlow Funcional Location

According to Content Modifier > Message Header, the used Source Value was /root/data/FunctionalLocation.

Content Modifier in iFlow Functional Location - Message Header

In the Exchange Property tab of the Content Modifier, we changed the second line entry to the Name p_functionallocation and its Source Value to /root/data/FunctionalLocation.

Content Modifier in iFlow Functional Location - Exchange Property

According to the Get Functional Location Data that will perform a GET operation to the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system, we used the OData Service for “API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION” with the root address /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION/. Note again that the API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION is activated in your on-premise system. You can check this via the transaction /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE and searching for the API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION OData Service. 

Request Reply with OData Adapter to SAP S/4HANA On-Premise System

In the Processing tab navigate to Select and go to Step 2 (As the fields required for the system connection will be filled automatically).

Choose the Operation and Select Entity as shown below with Sub Level 1 and Select All Fields.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration

Regarding the query, we were only filtering for FunctionalLocationLabelName equals ${property.p_functionallocation}.

The Message Mapping now needs to be performed for the Functional Location. Therefore, we used again the Resource /MM.mmap but now with a new mapping.

Message Mapping 1

Message Mapping 2

For the last OData Adapter sending the transformed Functional Location data from the SAP Integration Suite to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the Inbound Service URL for the Functional Location was used in the Address Field of the Connection Details.

Request Reply with OData Adapter to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud System - Connection

Inbound Service URL for Equipment in Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0395

According to the Processing details, the connection to the system will be again filled automatically. Then Navigate to Step 2 and choose the Select Entity as well as the Operation as shown below. Choose again Select All Fields.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration

3.4 Monitoring

Monitoring is a critical part of ensuring that event-driven integration for EHS Risk Management runs reliably across SAP S/4HANA (Public Cloud & On-Premise) and the SAP Integration Suite. Accurate and timely event processing is essential because many risk-related processes depend on these events. Missing or delayed events can lead to incomplete risk assessments, gaps in safety measures, and potential compliance violations.

The Monitoring can be performed at all three involved systems.

3.4.1 SAP S/4HANA On-Premise

Regarding the Outbound Events that are sent from the on-premise system to the SAP Integration Suite, you can navigate to SPRO > ABAP Platform > Enterprise Event Enablement > Monitoring > Monitor Event Queues.

If any failures for the Outbound Events occur, they can be analyzed here.

Event Monitor in SAP S/4HANA On-Premise System

3.4.2 SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, monitoring focuses on API communication rather than event queues. The primary tool that can be used here is the “OData Error Log” app, which provides detailed error messages for failed OData requests. This is essential for troubleshooting issues when SAP Integration Suite sends data to the Public Cloud system.

OData Error Log in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud System

3.4.3 SAP Integration Suite

SAP Integration Suite provides several tools to track and manage integrations flows. As already described already in the part 2 you can therefore navigate within the SAP Integration Suite to Monitor > Overview > Manage Integration Content. Here you can select your respective iFlow (e.g. “Functional Location Integration in between SAP S4HANA and SAP S4HANA Cloud”) and select Monitor Message Processing.

Manage Integration Content for Functional Location iFlow

This view provides a clear overview of the processing status for each message, indicating whether it was completed successfully or if any errors occurred during execution.

Monitor Message Processing

By selecting Message Status Overview on the upper right corner,  statistics will be shown across all processed messages, including completed, failed and retried executions. This provides a consolidated view of the integration scenario over a selected timeframe and supports quick identification of patterns or recurring issues. 

Message Status Overview

 

4. Lessons Learned

Implementing this integration scenario via the scope item 4HH for Plant Maintenance data (such as Functional Locations or Equipment) from the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provided several valuable insights that are highly relevant for similar integration projects.

1. Event-Driven Integration Ensures Real-Time Accuracy: Using SAP Event Mesh with AMQP is critical for keeping Functional Location and Equipment data synchronized. Batch jobs cannot guarantee timely updates for EHS processes like Risk Management.

2. Validate OData Services Early: Missing activation of API_EQUIPMENT or API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION in the on-premise system is a common root cause for iFlow failures. Always check via /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE before starting.

3. Topic Naming in Event Mesh Requires Precision: Incorrect prefixes or typos in topic subscriptions will block event processing entirely. Always cross-check against SAP Business Accelerator Hub references.

4. Message Mapping Is Compliance-Critical: Ensure that Equipment and Functional Location data is transformed correctly for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Missing mandatory fields can lead to incomplete risk assessments and reporting gaps.

5. Monitoring Is Essential for Operational Reliability: Event-driven integration depends on timely message processing. Use monitoring tools in all three systems (SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, SAP Integration Suite, and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud) to detect and resolve issues early.

6. Plan Authentication Strategy Upfront: Basic Authentication works for demos, but production environments require certificate-based authentication. Delaying this switch can cause project delays and security risks.

 

5. Engage with Us

To follow the series, make sure to subscribe to the SAP EHS Public Cloud blog tag.

We welcome your thoughts and feedback in the comments!

Acknowledgements

This blog post series is the result of close collaboration within our EHS implementation team. I would like to express my sincere appreciation to my colleagues, whose expertise, insights, and project experience significantly contributed to the depth and quality of this guide.

A special thank you goes to:

  • @Westphal
