  • @asutoshmaharana2326 
  • @kanwal_singh
  • @Suraj_Ashray1 

Their contributions were instrumental in shaping the content of this blog post. I am truly grateful for their collaborations and support.

entry.title: What's New in SAP Asset Performance Management 2511
entry.content:
This November release is a bumper edition and the most significant of the year for SAP Asset Performance Management. It brings Embedded IoT out of early adopter access into general availability, introduces new applications, built using SAP's Cloud Application Programming (CAP) model, opening exciting extensibility possibilities for asset management. And there are great enhancements for rules, industrial systems and recommendations. Here's an overview:

  • Embedded IoT is now available to all customers and partner
  • Managing Industrial Systems and Industrial System Templates Just Got Easier
  • New CAP Applications for Risk & Criticality Applications
  • Assign monitoring rules directly to proactive recommendations with the Condition subtype.
  • Copy standalone recommendations from both the object and list pages.
  • Navigate directly to maintenance plans or task lists in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.
  • Improvements to Rule Processing
    • Cleaner Data: Automatic Exclusion of Obsolete Technical Objects
    • Automatic Rule Triggering for New Measurement Data
  • Extensibility and Performance Improvements
  • Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition

Embedded IoT is now available to all customers and partners!

The centerpiece of this release is the general availability of Embedded IoT. Previously available only to early adopters, Embedded IoT now allows organizations to bring IoT device management and condition monitoring fully into SAP Asset Performance Management.

The launchpad of SAP Asset Performance Management now contains five new application tiles that are accessible to end-users depending on their assigned business roles. These tiles navigate directly to the respective applications in the embedded IoT platform:

You can:

  • Manage Devices – Onboard, configure, and control IoT devices across their lifecycle.
  • Map Devices to Technical Objects – Bring together operational technologies and IT technologies by linking devices and data points to technical objects and indicators for seamless integration.
  • Manage Streaming Rules – Process IoT signals and events in near real-time.
  • Manage IoT Dashboards – Central workspace for monitoring devices and visualizing insights.
  • IoT Platform Administration – Configure the embedded IoT platform, manage users, and control system-wide settings.

This brings true end-to-end asset monitoring into the hands of asset managers, with near real-time insights, automated rule triggering, and integrated dashboards for decision-making. For more information and videos, see the dedicated blog by Florian Weigold Embedded IoT is here: 5 apps that accelerate sensor to insight in SAP Asset Performance Management.

Managing Industrial Systems and Industrial System Templates Just Got Easier

See how the new 2511 features make a reliability engineer’s day smoother and more efficient.

Template Work: Reviewing and Updating

Your first job is to review an Industrial System Template with hundreds of elements. You open the Structure tab expecting the usual lag... but now, the Structure tab opens instantly in a new default table view for hierarchies with over three hundred elements providing a much better performance. A good start to the day! For more information, see Components of Industrial System Template Structure.

Soon after, a colleague asks who changed part of the template last week. With the new Change Logs , you find and export the full history in seconds. For more information, see View and Export Change Logs. Later, you want to make an update to the template, which is already released - something that wasn't possible before, now  - and even push the changes to all connected systems. 
A quick glance at the newly introduced Reference Designator Library Version in the table view confirms everything is aligned. 

By the end of the template review, you’ve worked faster, avoided workarounds, and ensured all templates are accurate and up to date.

Industrial System Work: Monitoring and Troubleshooting

After lunch, you move on to Industrial Systems. You create a new industrial system from a template: the structure stays fixed, while product aspects, descriptions, and organisational attributes remain editable. The new Synchronization Status instantly shows it’s up to date with the template.

Shortly after a technician calls: they need to take a pump sub-assembly offline for a quick check.
Before, you had to improvise workarounds. Now, you just deactivate the system element with one click. Once the check is complete, you reactivate it just as easily. For more information, see Activate or Deactivate a System Element.. 

Before you leave for the day you check the change logs for yesterday’s update — the pressure sensor mappings on Compressor 3 were adjusted in the control system during night shift, and you can see exactly who changed what and when.

Two minutes later, a colleague pings you “Can you check Compressor 3? The output readings don’t seem right.” You open the system’s structure — enormous with over three hundred interconnected elements that used to freeze your screen — but today, just like the template, it loads instantly in the optimized table view, so you can spot the mismatch immediately.

While you’re there, you quickly verify the reference designator library version to ensure the system is aligned with the latest engineering release. Everything matches.  You also check the Organizational Attributes in the system’s Excel export to confirm that ownership and responsibilities are up to date. For more information see Creating an Industrial System from Excel and Export or Import Sytem Structure

Thanks to the recent API migration from the Asset Health package to the Manage Asset Data package, your scripts and integrations run smoothly without any hiccups. For more information, refer to Manage Asset Data API

By the end of the day, you've worked faster, with more clarity and fewer workarounds — thanks to thoughtful enhancements across both templates and systems.

In a nutshell:

  • Industrial systems and templates can now display reference designator library versions, track change logs, and synchronize with templates for better alignment.
  • Large system hierarchies default to table view for faster navigation, improving usability in complex environments.
  • Released templates can be edited and changes pushed to associated systems, giving teams more flexibility to evolve structures without losing control.
  • System elements can now be activated or deactivated, and limited edits to systems created from templates are supported.
  • Together, these improvements make the platform more responsive, adaptable, and ready for advanced use cases.

We will be releasing a dedicated blog on industrial systems and template next week. Watch this space.

New CAP Applications for Risk & Criticality Applications

With the 2511 release, we’re introducing two new CAP-based applications: Manage Templates for Risk & Criticality Assessments and Manage Risk & Criticality Assessments. These CAP apps bring a more modern, scalable, and extensible architecture, delivering smoother performance and a more consistent user experience. 

You can enable the new CAP-based apps by adding the new authorization scope (RiskCriticality_CAP) to the users. Watch this space for a dedicated blog in the coming weeks.

For more information on release timelines, implementation, support, and known limitations, refer to SAP Note 3603407

Entry Point to New CAP-Based Applications for Risk and Criticality on SAP Fiori Launchpad

 Asset Reliability Engineering

Recommendations have become even more actionable:

Assign monitoring rules directly to proactive recommendations with the Condition subtype.

With the 2511 release, APM restores an important capability: assigning IoT monitoring rules to proactive condition-based recommendations. This was available in the earlier SAP IoT solution, but the new embedded IoT version delivers it on a stronger and more modern foundation - a more powerful rules application and a new, independent dataset application.

This evolved architecture makes the connection between IoT rules and APM recommendations cleaner, more flexible, and easier to extend than it was in sIoT. Instead of simply copying the old behaviour, APM now integrates with IoT rules in a way that matches the newer, more capable platform.

What problem are we solving?

Before the ability to assign eIoT monitoring rules, proactive condition-based recommendations were largely static. Maintenance teams could see a recommendation, but there was no automated way to know when it actually needed attention. Decisions about timing relied on manual monitoring, scheduled inspections, or guesswork, which could lead to reactive maintenance, unnecessary work, or missed opportunities to prevent failures. Recommendations lacked the proper context from real-time sensor data, making it difficult to prioritize actions effectively or ensure maintenance was truly condition-driven.

The new CAP recommendation app now includes a dedicated section for assigning embedded IoT monitoring rules. Once a rule is linked, APM can automatically react when that rule detects an unusual pattern in the sensor data.

Rule creation will follow in a future release. Rules - and their associated datasets — must be created separately in their own applications. 

For more information, refer to Implementing a Proactive Type Condition Recommendation.

Watch this quick demo:

Video demo showing how to assign monitoring rules to proactive condition-based recommendations in the new CAP-based Implement Recommendations app

UI improvements

Information for rules is now in the recommendation column of the Implement Recommendations list page. You can click on the rule(s) associated with the recommendation and see a popup, from where you can navigate directly to the Manage Rules and Manage Datasets apps.

UI enhancements for rules in the Implement Recommendations app

Copy standalone recommendations from both the object and list pages.

You can now copy a standalone recommendation with and without coding mask from both the object page and the list page in the Manage Recommendations app.

In many reliability and maintenance processes, teams often create multiple recommendations that are nearly identical, especially when working across similar assets, recurring failure modes, or repeated strategy decisions. Until now, every recommendation had to be created manually from scratch, even when most of the content already existed elsewhere.

The new Copy Recommendation function solves this problem. You take an existing standalone recommendation and create a new one with the same core information already prefilled. This includes the recommendation details and notes, but intentionally not the comments—because comments usually reflect a specific discussion on the original recommendation and shouldn’t be carried forward.

The copied recommendation is treated as a new object with no linkage or lineage to the source—just a convenient head start.

Business Value

  • Speed: Reduces effort when creating multiple similar recommendations.

  • Consistency: Ensures repeated recommendations follow the same structure and information.

  • Quality: Minimises manual entry errors by reusing accurate, validated data.

  • Scalability: Particularly valuable during large strategy projects, where dozens or hundreds of recommendations need to be generated efficiently.

For more information, refer to Copying a Recommendation.

Example: Copy recommendation with coding mask in Manage Recommendations app

Navigate directly to maintenance plans or task lists in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

To make maintenance workflows more efficient, we added direct navigation from recommendations to the related Task List or Maintenance Plan. Customers can configure the Launchpad URL for their environment, and the system generates links that open the correct object in the corresponding application.

This eliminates the need to search manually, saving time and reducing errors. Teams can move seamlessly from identifying an issue to implementing the required actions, improving efficiency and traceability across large maintenance projects.

To navigate to SAP S/4HANA system to view maintenance list details, you have configured the destination information in the BTP cockpit. For more information, see Creating a Maintenance Plan for Recommendation and Creating a Task List for Recommendation.

 

Improvements to Rule Processing

We have introduced two improvements to enhance the accuracy and automation of rule-based monitoring across SAP Asset Performance Management.

What Problem Are We Solving?

Until now, aggregation rules could be affected by irrelevant technical objects (for example, objects already inactive or marked for deletion) and sometimes required manual intervention to trigger rule execution when new measurement data arrived. This led to inconsistent results, unnecessary noise in aggregated values, and additional effort for reliability engineers.

What’s New

Cleaner Data: Automatic Exclusion of Obsolete Technical Objects

When creating new aggregation rules, child technical objects with the statuses  Inactive, Marked for Deletion, or Deleted are now automatically excluded.  This ensures that only valid and active parts of your asset structure contribute to aggregated calculations, resulting in more accurate monitoring and fewer irrelevant results. For more information, see Creating an Aggregation Rule.

Automatic Rule Triggering for New Measurement Data

Rules using the Measurement Document Ingestion trigger now run automatically when:

  • A measurement document is replicated from SAP S/4HANA
  • A new indicator value is created manually

This eliminates manual steps, ensures rules react immediately to fresh data, and helps reliability engineers maintain up-to-date insights without intervention. For more information, see Triggering a Rule.

 

Extensibility and Performance Improvements

With the new CAP applications, this also opens the door to greater extensibility, allowing organizations to adapt applications and processes to their unique needs. Watch this space for a dedicated blog on how to configure the CAP apps to enable extensibility. Coming soon!

Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition

The 2025 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition brings deeper integration with SAP Asset Performance Management (APM). APM recommendations, indicators, and assessments are now visible directly in the Find Technical Objects app, together with risk and criticality information. In addition, APM failure data relationships can now be used to select Failure Modes and Failure Effects during maintenance processes, ensuring the right task lists are assigned and actions are aligned with historical recommendations.

For full details, read Fernanda Rodrigues' blog Asset Management in SAP Cloud ERP Private 2025 Release and explore Fernanda's other blogs too.

Stay Informed and Get Involved

  • Find out what's up and coming in the SAP Road Map Explorer.
  • For an exhaustive list of all new features, visit the SAP Help Portal - What's New in SAP Asset Performance Management.. 
  • Send us your improvement requests. Submit or vote for the improvement you would like to see in the SAP Continuous Influence session.
  • Check the APM link collection. 

Let us know what you think about these new features - leave us a comment below or ask a question! 

See you soon for the 2512 update!

entry.title: 4 Important enhancements related to Object type in SAP PM
entry.content:
Here are the top four important enhancements related to object type in SAP PM:

  1. Default value of authorization group: The object type can be proposed for motors, pumps, compressors, electrical distribution lines, transmission lines, assembly lines, etc. Now for each of the object types there can be a default value of authorization group. We can maintain those values in a Z table. If any new object type is introduced, a default value can be added. The user can add the respective value of the authorization group later on.
  2. Default value of Planner group: Planner groups generally work for a specific department or specific type of machine. In such a situation we can determine a specific planner group based on object type. This can be done by enhancing and maintaining the planner group and object type in the Z table.
  3. Determine the catalog profile based on the type of object type: The catalog profile is very important for adding technical findings in the form of codes in a notification. The catalog profile should be specific to the technical object or technical object type. So, you can maintain a catalog profile and object type in a Z table and determine the catalog profile automatically at the time of creating a technical object. At the time of creating a notification, the catalog profile is determined automatically as a part of the standard SAP feature.
  4. Determine the class and assign it to the equipment: You can determine the class automatically with respect to object type. For example, for object type "electrical pole," you can do an enhancement to determine its respective class automatically. You need to maintain the class and object type in a z table. It helps to assign the correct class to the technical object.

 

You can use user exit IEQM0003 for the check at the time of saving the equipment.

You can use the BAPI => BAPI_OBJCL_CHANGE to assign the class as per the object type in a equipment.

Regards,

Vaibhav Mishra

entry.title: How to Connect a OPC-UA Device to SAP Asset Performance Management
entry.content:
Introduction

New month, new big release! With version 2511 of SAP Asset Performance Management (APM), the Embedded IoT capabilities powered by Cumulocity reached General Availability (GA) status. In this post from the Asset Performance Management product team, you can get an overview of the 4 IoT applications that are now available to SAP Asset Performance Management customers.

To celebrate this next milestone, we (the topic experts from Cumulocity) wanted to share our next guide with you as a follow-up on our post where we showed how you can easily connect your smartphone to get started quickly.

Overview

To get started with SAP Asset Performance Management and connect real-world machines, you can leverage existing device protocols like OPC-UA. In this guide, we demonstrate how to use the Embedded IoT platform (powered by Cumulocity) to connect physical devices via OPC-UA and correlate them with assets provided by SAP Asset Performance Management.

We will leverage multiple components in this scenario:

  • Simulated pumps with an OPC-UA client
  • Thin-edge.io running an OPC-UA Server and the Cumulocity OPC-UA Gateway to transfer the data to Cumulocity
  • Cumulocity as an embedded IoT cloud system and capabilities like
    • Device Management
      • OPC-UA Remote Management
      • Software Management
      • Cloud OT Protocol Mapping using Device Protocols

    • Cockpit
      • Dashboarding

    • Digital Twin Manager
      • Mapping & Correlating Device data to Asset data in SAP Asset Performance Management

  • SAP Asset Performance Management
    • Asset Data Management
    • Maintenance Rules & Alert Management

Let’s get started!

Prerequisites

To follow this guide, the following prerequisites must be fulfilled:

  • You have access to an SAP Asset Performance Management instance including Embedded IoT platform.
  • You have Docker and Docker Compose installed on your machine. We will use them to simulate a device, including an OPC-UA simulation server.

Step-by-Step Guide

1. Start thin-edge.io demo container

To simulate a device that runs an OPC-UA + simulation server, we leverage thin-edge.io, which is a powerful open-source edge framework that can connect with ease to the embedded IoT platform Cumulocity. For demonstration purposes, there is a demo container available that installs thin-edge with tons of pre-installed and configured plugins that let us manage the device fully remotely, showcasing the power of the Cumulocity platform.

First of all, you need to download a docker compose file:

curl -LSs https://raw.githubusercontent.com/thin-edge/tedge-demo-container/main/demos/docker-compose/device/docker-compose.yaml > docker-compose.yaml

Or using wget:

wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/thin-edge/tedge-demo-container/main/demos/docker-compose/device/docker-compose.yaml

Before we start the container, we need to register it in Cumulocity. From within SAP Asset Performance Management launchpad, navigate to the “Manage Devices” application to sign-in to the Embedded IoT platform.

Within “Device Management” navigate to “Management” → “Trusted Certificates”. Here click on “Add CA Certificate” in the top right toolbar which will add the CA certificate to the tenant which is used to issue new device certificates. Please note: If you already have the CA certificate added, the button “Add CA certificate” is disabled and you can proceed.

Navigate to “Devices” -> “Registration”. Please remember & save your tenant URL from your browser address bar. You need to provide it in some steps below, e.g.:

https://<Your Cumulocity Tenant URL, ending with *.iot.sap>/apps/devicemanagement/index.html#/deviceregistration

Click on “Register device” → “General”.

Toggle to create device certificate during device registration and enter the following:

  • Device ID: ThinEdge-cooling-line3
  • One-time password: in4mU32icNVjj3c
    (Important: This password here is just for demonstration purposes. Replace this with any secret token of your choice)

Click on “Next” to create the device registration.

Next you can start the demo container with the following command in the folder where you have downloaded the docker-compose.yaml to:

docker compose up -d

Afterwards we need to bootstrap it with the following commands (take the domain for the saved tenant URL).

docker compose exec tedge tedge config set c8y.url <Your Cumulocity Tenant domain without https://>

And (replace the one-time password with your selected password)

docker compose exec tedge tedge cert download c8y --device-id ThinEdge-cooling-line3 --one-time-password in4mU32icNVjj3c

Finally we need to connect thin-edge:

docker compose exec tedge tedge connect c8y

 

In the „Device Management“ application, you should now see the thin-edge device with the Name “ThinEdge-cooling-line-3”.

2. Make OPC-UA Gateway & OPC-UA Simulation Server available via Software Repository

Great, thin-edge devices are up and running! As a next step, we want to create a Cumulocity OPC-UA gateway within the demo container that allows us to establish a connection to an OPC-UA server.

Cumulocity in combination with thin-edge allows to remotely deploy and run Docker containers directly from the Cumulocity Device Management application in your browser. Therefore, there is no need to go to any console, do a Docker pull or run; it can be all done within the Device Management App of Cumulocity. To do this, we need to create so-called software artifacts, which contain a docker-compose.yml file.

Luckily, there is another thin-edge repository that does the job for us: https://github.com/thin-edge/opcua-device-gateway-container

For our purpose, we can use the following Docker Compose file:

https://raw.githubusercontent.com/thin-edge/opcua-solution-blueprint/refs/heads/main/software/docker-compose-opcua-device-gateway-demo-container.yml

Within SAP Asset Performance Management, navigate to the “Manage Devices” application -> Management -> Software Repository.

Click on “Add Software” and provide the following information. Select “Upload File” and select the docker-compose.yml file you created in the previous step.

  • Software: OPC-UA Gateway
  • Description: Container to run OPC-UA Gateway within tedge demo container
  • Device type filter: thin-edge.io
  • Software type: container-group
  • Version: 1.0.0
  • Provide a file path: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/thin-edge/opcua-solution-blueprint/refs/heads/main/software/docker-compose-opcua-device-gateway-demo-container.yml

 

Repeat the step for adding an OPC-Server that simulates data but using the following Docker Compose file and details:

  • Software: OPC-UA Demo Server
  • Description: OPC-UA Demo Server that simulates device data
  • Device type filter: thin-edge.io
  • Software type: container-group
  • Version: 1.0.0
  • Provide a file path: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/thin-edge/opcua-solution-blueprint/refs/heads/main/software/docker-compose-opcua-demo-server.yml

In the end, you should have two software entries added in the Software Repository:

 

3. Install Cumulocity OPC-UA Gateway & OPC-UA Simulation Server

With the software artifacts for the Cumulocity OPC-UA Gateway and the OPC-UA Simulation Server created successfully, we want to install them in our thin-edge demo container by using the Device Management capabilities.

Within “Manage Devices”, navigate to “Devices” -> “All devices” and search for “ThinEdge-cooling-line3,” which should return our thin-edge demo container.

When clicking on the device, we see all the capabilities. One capability of the thin-edge demo container is to install software remotely via the “Software” Tab. At the bottom, click on “Install software.” In the opened windows, you should see the opc-ua gateway & opc-ua simulator. Select for both the version “1.0.0” and click on “Install.”

Finally, start the installation process by clicking on “Apply changes.”After a short time, you should see that both components were successfully installed.You can confirm success by selecting the “Services” Tab. The opc-ua demo server and opc-ua gateway should be listed there.

4. Configure the OPC-UA Server

Now that both components are installed and running in our thin-edge demo container, we need to configure them. Continuing on the “ThinEdge-cooling-line3” device, navigate to “Child devices.” You should see a new child device named “OPCUAGateway”, please select it.

There, you can find a Tab called “OPC UA server.” Click on “Add server” and provide the following information:

  • Server name: OPC-UA Demo Server
  • Server URL: opc.tcp://opcserver:4840

Keep all other settings to default and “Save” the server.

With the connection to the server configured, the “Child Devices” Tab now shows an established server connection that appears as another child device called “OPC-UA Demo Server”. Click on it and select “Address space” to check the simulated and provided objects and sensors. Please note that it will take a few minutes for the address space scan to complete. The “Pump01” is especially interesting as it will be used in the next step.

5. Create Device Protocol

With the simulated pump connected via OPC-UA we can map data from the pump object to the Cumulocity domain model. We will do that by creating a so-called “Device Protocol”

From SAP Asset Performance Management, navigate again to the “Manage Devices” application which takes you seamlessly to the “Device Management” capability in Cumulocity. The device protocols can be defined in “Device Types” -> “Device Protocols”. Click on “Add device protocol”, select “OPC UA” and provide the following information:

  • Name: Pump01
  • Description: Device Type for Pump01
  • Reference server: OPC-UA Demo Server
  • Select “Root” node

When clicking on “Create” you can configure the variables. Click on “Add variable”. Navigate to Pump01 and select “flow”.Toggle measurement with the following settings:

  • Type: flow
  • Series: flow
  • Unit: l/m

Click “Save”.

Repeat the steps for “bearingTemperature”:

  • Type: bearingTemperature
  • Series: bearingTemperature
  • Unit: C

And finally “power”:

  • Type: power
  • Series: power
  • Unit: W

If you want you can also create the other variables like described in the screenshot below:

In the “Data Reporting” section select “Cyclic read” with a reading interval of “3000” msec. Finally activate (on top) and save the Device Protocol.

Navigate back to “Devices”. You should see a new Device there called “Pump01” that represents the created protocol definition. When clicking on “Measurements” and activating real-time by clicking on the dot in the top you should see the values coming in.

6. Creating Indicators in SAP Asset Performance Management

With the data available in Cumulocity you can now focus on assigning it to technical objects from SAP Asset Performance Management. This step bridges the OT and IT world, bringing device semantics into the process and master data context from the IT world. In our case, we assign the simulated pump to a "Cooling Water Circulation Pump" but you can assign it to any other asset of your choice as available in your system. To proceed with assigning the sensors, you need a representation of them as indicators in SAP Asset Performance Management. Follow thedocumentation to create three indicators:

  • Pump Bearing Temperature
  • Pump Flow Rate
  • Motor Power

7. Assign Data Points to Indicators

SAP Asset Performance Management automatically provisions Technical Objects along with their indicators into the Embedded IoT platform for data contextualization. From the Asset Performance Management launchpad, open the “Map Devices to Assets” application, which navigates to the “Digital Twin Manager” within Cumulocity.

Use the search in the top right area to search for the identifier of your Technical Object (e.g. 217100093 from the screenshot above, or any parent object such as 1710) to easily open the corresponding asset. The indicators are shown with their nomenclature from SAP Asset Performance Management and can now be “linked” to their corresponding measurements/series from the OPC UA protocol definition via the “Link source” button.

After successful assignment, the measurement data will be made available within SAP Asset Performance Management.

8. Review data in SAP Asset Performance Management

You can validate that time series data from your simulation server is now available on the Technical Object for further processing within SAP Asset Performance Management. Open the “Explore Technical Objects” application and navigate to the “Cooling Water Circulation Pump”. On the “Indicator Monitoring” tab, you can see the incoming data in the time series chart.

Please note that it can take up to 90 minutes until data is available in Asset Performance Management.

Conclusion & Next Steps

This guide demonstrated how you can connect an industrial device via OPC-UA to Embedded IoT powered by Cumulocity and assign its measurement data to an existing technical object in SAP Asset Performance Management.

This described setup uses a simulated pump. If you want to leverage OPC-UA in a productive use case, you may follow the steps described here: https://github.com/thin-edge/opcua-solution-blueprint?tab=readme-ov-file#production-like-deployment-examples

Doing so you would not use the thin-edge demo container, but install thin-edge.io locally on a gateway that has access to an already available OPC-UA server where devices are already connected to, or utilizing a certified device from Cumulocity’s extensive hardware partner catalog.

entry.title: Extending SAP Asset Performance Management: Three Approaches to Tailoring Your Asset Operations
entry.content:
In asset management, no two organizations operate the same way. While standard software provides a robust foundation, the ability to adapt to industry-specific regulations and distinct business processes is where you find your true efficiency.

At SAP, we understand this need for flexibility. That's why SAP Asset Performance Management (APM) is built on a modern, cloud-native architecture designed to be extended. Whether you are a customer, partner, or consultant, this blog highlights how you can leverage APM’s extensibility options to build tailored, value-added solutions.

 

Why Extensibility Matters

Extensibility is not just a technical feature - it's what makes APM work the way your business actually runs. By extending the solution, you can:

  • Address industry-specific needs by closing functional gaps that matter in your daily operations.
  • Enhance user productivity with role-focused UIs that cut out unnecessary clicks and complexities.
  • Integrate seamlessly with your existing IT landscape without disrupting the core application.

Here are the three main ways you can customize APM. The first two methods are also collectively known as SaaS Extensibility.

1. Extending Data and Services (OData APIs)

The foundation of any custom solution is data. APM provides robust OData APIs that let you add new data fields without modifying the core structure.

What You Can Do

A. Add custom fields and custom entities

Need to track "Compliance Due Date" or the "Safety Criticality Level" on a specific recommendation? You can extend existing entities with additional fields or create entirely new entities to capture this critical information, without changing the standard application model.

  • Custom entities are customer-defined data structures that allow organizations to store and manage business information beyond the standard application model.
  • Custom fields are customer-defined attributes added to an existing entities to capture additional business-specific information.

B. Build custom applications

Develop custom applications using extended services (APIs) to introduce new business logic or functionalities that complement APM.

=> Learn how to extend ODATA APIs in CAP: Extending the Data Model

2. Customizing the User Interface (UI)

Once you have the right data, you need to present it effectively. APM offers robust options for extending SAP Fiori-based applications to match your workflow.

What You Can Do:

  • Show Your Custom Fields: Make your custom data (like that "Compliance Due Date") visible as a new column in lists like Manage Recommendations or as a new field in details pages.
  • Organize Information: Group related information together. For example, you could create a specific "Safety Assessment and Financial Analysis" tab on the Recommendation page to put all risk mitigation and cost benefit details in one easy to find spot.
  • Smart Controls: Change how data looks and control how fields are rendered – like changing a text input to a dropdown list for consistency or reordering fields to prioritize key data.

=> Learn how to extend UI5 Fiori based applications: Extending UI Annotations

Example 1: Recommendation Object Page showing new custom fields for Version tracking in the Header and Information section.

Example 2: Recommendation Object Page showing a custom 'Attachments' tab with external links and sensitivity details

Example 3: Recommendation Object Page showing new custom fields for ‘Integrity Critical’ and ‘Run-to-Fail' status

 

Example 4: Recommendation List Page showing new columns and filters for custom fields - Version, Integrity Criticality, Run to Fail status

 

3. Adapting for Different Users

Different people need different things. APM leverages the SAPUI5 Extensibility framework, offering three levels of customization so everyone has the right view.

A. End User Personalization ("My View")

  • Who: Individual Users

  • What: Users can save their own filter settings as "Variants" (e.g., "Critical Rotor Failures Q3"), add shortcuts to objects you use often, and move applications around on the Fiori Launchpad.

  • Why: Increases individual efficiency without requiring IT support.

=> Learn more about SAPUI5 Flexibility for End Users: End User Personalization

B. Key User Adaptation ("Our View")

  • Who: Business Experts / Key Users
  • What: Using intuitive, no-code tools, key users can adapt the UI for entire teams. This includes hiding irrelevant fields, renaming labels to match internal terminology, or creating shared views for specific roles (e.g., an "Operations View" vs. a "Reliability View").
  • Why: Tailors the application for specific teams without writing custom code.

=> Learn more about SAPUI5 Flexibility for Key Users: Key User Adaptation

=> How to Begin with Key User Adaptation: Adapting SAP Fiori UIs at Runtime

C. Developer Adaptation ("Custom Code")

  • Who: Professional Developers

  • What: For complex requirements, developers can use SAP Business Application Studio to inject custom UI components, integrate external data services, or implement complex logic.

  • Why: Solves unique, complex business challenges while keeping the core app safe and updatable.

Note: Developer Adaptation is currently not supported in APM.

 

Getting Started

We want to make extending APM as easy as possible. To help you start quickly, we provide:

  • Template Projects: Downloadable SAP CAP projects pre-configured for extending specific APM applications. These include the basic code and test data to speed up development.
  • Step-by-Step Guides: Step-by-step documentation covering everything from setting up your test tenant to deploying and maintaining your extensions.

Best Practices for Success

To ensure your extensions are robust and future-proof, keep these principles in mind:

  • Don't Break the Core: Always use the provided frameworks (OData extensions, UI Adaptation) rather than modifying core code.
  • Focus on Value: Focus on extensions that address a clear business need and add tangible value to your users.
  • Design for Stability: Write clean, modular and secure code that is easy to maintain and scale.
  • Keep it Secure: Adhere to SAP security guidelines for data access and authorization.
  • Performance Aware: Make sure you extensions don’t slow down the core application, especially if you are working with large datasets.
  • Test Rigorously: Ensure your extensions function correctly under various scenarios.

Conclusion

Extensibility is the key to getting the most out of your asset management strategy. By leveraging these tools, you can transform APM into a solution that fits your business perfectly - driving greater efficiency, intelligence, and operational excellence.

Ready to get started? Check out the official documentation and our architectural guidelines to begin tailoring APM to your unique needs today.
